    • Writing Checks

Writing Checks

Source: vignettes/writing-checks.Rmd
writing-checks.Rmd
library(chex)

Basic checks

At its core, checks are just predicate functions, which return TRUE or FALSE values, which are converted to pass and fail results. rlang-style lambdas are also accepted. These checks are passed to check_that() along with an input value.

is_count <- function(x) {
  is.integer(x) & x > 0
}

check_that(1L, is_count, ~.x == 2L)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [2] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... is_count
#> ✖ FAIL ... ~.x == 2L

Checks can also return multiple logical values, which are converted into multiple results.


check_that(-3:3, is_count)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [7] ──
#> ✖ FAIL ... is_count
#> ✖ FAIL ... is_count
#> ✖ FAIL ... is_count
#> ✖ FAIL ... is_count
#> ✔ PASS ... is_count
#> ✔ PASS ... is_count
#> ✔ PASS ... is_count

Descriptions

In the examples above, the check results show the description (e.g. is_count) in addition to the pass or fail value. This description can be customized a few different ways.

Named checks

The easiest way to add a custom description is to name your check when calling check_that():

x <- 1L
check_that(x, "`x` is a count" = is_count)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... `x` is a count

set_description()

If you want to add a more permanent custom description, use the set_description() function.

is_count_set <- set_description(is_count, "`x` is a count")
description(is_count_set)
#> [1] "`x` is a count"

check_that(x, is_count_set)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... `x` is a count

When you name a check which already has a description set by set_description() the name will take precedence.

check_that(x, "overriding set description" = is_count_set)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... overriding set description

Dynamic descriptions

Sometimes in advanced use-cases, the description needs to be set dynamically from within the check function itself. This can be accomplished using, the current_check() function along with set_description(), which we saw above:

is_count_dynamic <- function(x) {
  set_description(current_check(), "dynamically set")
  is_count(x)
}

check_that(x, is_count_dynamic)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... dynamically set

When used with a named description, the named description is used:

check_that(x, "named descriptions win" = is_count_dynamic)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... named descriptions win

Returning results

You can also return a result object with a description already attached to it. This takes higher precedence than any description that was set using set_description() whether beforehand or dynamically, but has lower precedence than named descriptions.

is_count_result <- function(x) {
  set_description(current_check(), "not used")
  result(is_count(x), "x is a count")
}

check_that(x, is_count_result)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... x is a count

check_that(x, "named descriptions always win" = is_count_result)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... named descriptions always win

Custom S3 class

The final method of adding custom descriptions is the most advanced. This requires creating a custom S3 class and some S3 methods for the class. For example:

my_check <- structure(class = c("my_check", "function"), function(x) {
  TRUE 
})
class(my_check)
#> [1] "my_check" "function"

Then you can create a description() method for your class:

description.my_check <- function(x, ...) {
  "my check custom description"
}
description(my_check)
#> [1] "my check custom description"

check_that(mtcars, my_check)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... my check custom description

This will work, unless your custom S3 class also returns a result object. In the examples above we see that returning a result takes precedence over a set description. However, with a custom S3 class, you can also write a run_check() method to further customize the behavior:

my_check <- structure(class = c("my_check", "function"), function(x) {
  result(TRUE, "this will be used, not the `my check custom description`")
})

# the result description is used, not the check description
check_that(mtcars, my_check) 
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... this will be used, not the `my check custom description`


# Now define a run_check method. The `check` parameter is your custom check.
run_check.my_check <- function(check, x) {
  result <- check(x) # run your check manually
  set_description(result, "now this overwrites the result description")
}

# now we have full control
check_that(mtcars, my_check)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✔ PASS ... now this overwrites the result description

Reason

Sometimes when a check fails, there will be text beneath the result output which explains why the check failed. This can happen, for example, when a check throws an error. This is called the “reason”.

check_that(mtcars, function(x) stop("bad. bad. really, really, bad."))
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✖ FAIL ... function(x) stop("bad. bad. really, really, bad.")
#> bad. bad. really, really, bad.

You can add a custom reason to your checks, by either throwing and error using stop() or by returning the result of the FAIL function:

less_than_five <- function(x) {
  if (x >= 5) {
    return(FAIL("x is not less than 5"))
  } 
  TRUE
}

check_that(5, less_than_five)
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [1] ──
#> ✖ FAIL ... less_than_five
#> x is not less than 5

Check factories

One useful pattern for creating checks is to use a factory. This way you can use a generic template to create many parameterized check functions. For example, the less_than_five() check in the example above could be parameterized instead of the 5 being hard-coded:

is_less_than_n <- function(n) {
  check <- function(x) {
    if (x >= n) {
      return(FAIL(paste0("x is not be less than ", n, ": x = ", x)))
    }
    TRUE
  }
  set_description(check, paste("x is less than", n))
}

check_that(7, is_less_than_n(n = 5), is_less_than_n(n = 10))
#> ── RESULTS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── [2] ──
#> ✖ FAIL ... x is less than 5
#> x is not be less than 5: x = 7
#> ✔ PASS ... x is less than 10
